name: Acute Cholecystitis
clerking:
Golden Questions (5)
  • "Does the pain radiate to your right shoulder/back?" (Boas Sign - Phrenic nerve irritation C3,4,5)
  • "Did this start after a fatty meal?" (CCK release contracts GB against obstruction)
  • "How long has the pain lasted? >6 hours?" (Distinguishes from Biliary Colic)
  • "Have you had fevers or shivers?" (Suggests inflammation/infection)
  • "Has your urine become dark or stools pale?" (Complicated - CBD stone)
Differential Diagnosis (5)
  • Biliary Colic: Pain <6h, No fever, Normal WBC.
  • Peptic Ulcer: Burning epigastric pain, association with hunger/food.
  • Right Lower Lobe Pneumonia: Respiratory symptoms, fever, decreased breath sounds.
  • Acute Pancreatitis: Radiates to back, amylase high.
  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome: Perihepatitis associated with PID.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

The primary symptom typically begins as diffuse or periumbilical abdominal pain that eventually localizes to the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ). The pain is constant and severe, lasting >6 hours. It may radiate to the right scapula (Boas' sign) or shoulder tip (referred pain via phrenic nerve).
Aggravating Factors: Pain may worsen when taking a deep breath, walking, squatting, or riding in a car (peritoneal irritation).
Associated Symptoms: Anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills/rigors.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

95% calculous (obstruction of cystic duct by gallstone -> distension -> ischemia -> infection). 5% acalculous (stasis/ischemia in critically ill).
Common Organisms: E. coli (Most common), Klebsiella, Enterococcus, Bacteroides.
Risk Factors (5 F's): Fat, Female, Forty, Fertile, Fair. Hemolytic anemia. Rapid weight loss.
exam:
Signs

Tachycardia, Pyrexia. Patient lies still to avoid pain.
Abdomen: RUQ tenderness/guarding.
Murphy's Sign: Inspiratory arrest on deep palpation of RUQ (positive only if negative on left).
Red Flags: Generalized peritonitis (Perforation), Jaundice (Mirizzi/CBD stone).
inv:
Bedside

Urine Dip (Exclude renal colic/UTI/DKA). ECG (Rule out inferior MI).

Labs

FBC (Leukocytosis), CRP (High), LFTs (Mild derangement), Amylase (Exclude pancreatitis).

Imaging

USG Abdomen (Gold Standard):
- Thickened GB wall >3mm.
- Pericholecystic fluid.
- Presence of gallstones/sludge.
- Positive sonographic Murphy's sign.
- Distended gallbladder (>4cm width).
mgmt:
Resuscitation

NBM, IV Fluids, Analgesia (NSAIDs/Opioids).

Medical

IV Antibiotics (Cefuroxime + Metronidazole).

Surgical

Early Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy (<72h of onset).

Interventional

Percutaneous Cholecystostomy (Drainage) for Tokyo Grade III/High risk.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Empyema of Gallbladder: Pus filled GB (Sepsis).
  • Gangrenous Cholecystitis: Ischemia/Perforation.
  • Biliary Peritonitis: Rupture.
  • Cholecystoenteric Fistula: Leads to Gallstone Ileus.
Treatment Related
  • Bile Duct Injury (0.3%).
  • Bile Leak.
  • Retained Stone.
  • Post-cholecystectomy Syndrome.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Tokyo Guidelines 2018
Grade I (Mild) -> Lap Chole. Grade II (Moderate) -> Abx then Surgery. Grade III (Severe) -> Drainage.
ðŸ’Ž Mirizzi Syndrome
Stone impacted in Cystic duct compressing Common Hepatic Duct -> Jaundice.
ðŸ’Ž Boas' Sign
Hyperaesthesia below the right scapula (T9-T11) due to phrenic nerve irritation.

name: Gallstones (Biliary Colic)
clerking:
Golden Questions (5)
  • "Does the pain come and go?"
  • "Does it go away completely between attacks?"
  • "Is your urine dark or eyes yellow?" (Rule out CBD stone)
  • "Did this happen after eating greasy food?"
  • "Any fever or shivers?" (Rule out Cholecystitis)
Differential Diagnosis (5)
  • Acute Cholecystitis: Fever, pain >6h.
  • Gastritis/GERD: Burning pain.
  • Pancreatitis: Back radiation, severe.
  • Peptic Ulcer: Hunger pain.
  • Renal Colic: Loin to groin.
history:
HOPI

Colicky RUQ/Epigastric pain, post-prandial (fatty food). Lasts <6 hours. No fever. Nausea/Vomiting common. Pain resolves completely.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Temporary obstruction of cystic duct by stone. Contraction against blockage causes pain.
Stone Types: Cholesterol (Mixed) - 80%, Pigment (Black/Brown) - 20%.
Risks: 5 Fs, Hemolysis, Crohn's (bile salt malabsorption).
exam:
Signs

Abdomen soft/non-tender between attacks. Negative Murphy's. Afebrile. No jaundice.
inv:
Labs

Normal WBC, CRP, LFTs (Crucial negative findings).

Imaging

USG Abdomen: Stones with acoustic shadowing. Thin GB wall (<3mm). No fluid.
mgmt:
Conservative

Analgesia (Diclofenac > Opioids), Low fat diet.

Surgical

Elective Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy to prevent complications.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Acute Cholecystitis.
  • Choledocholithiasis (Jaundice/Cholangitis).
  • Gallstone Pancreatitis.
  • Gallstone Ileus.
  • Mucocele of GB.
Treatment Related
  • Bile Duct Injury.
  • Bleeding.
  • Infection.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Saint's Triad
Gallstones + Diverticulosis + Hiatus Hernia.
ðŸ’Ž Mercedes Benz Sign
Gas within a gallstone (fissures) seen on CT/X-ray.

name: Acute Pancreatitis
clerking:
Golden Questions (5)
  • "Does the pain go straight through to your back?"
  • "Does sitting forward help?"
  • "Do you drink alcohol? How much?"
  • "History of gallstones?"
  • "Any recent ERCP or trauma?"
Differential Diagnosis (5)
  • Perforated PUD: Air under diaphragm.
  • Acute Cholecystitis: RUQ pain, Murphy's +.
  • MI: ECG changes.
  • Ruptured AAA: Shock, Pulsatile mass.
  • Mesenteric Ischemia: Pain out of proportion.
history:
HOPI

Sudden severe epigastric pain radiating to back (transfixion). "Boring" pain. Vomiting does not relieve pain.
Causes (GET SMASHED): Gallstones (50%), Alcohol (30%), Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion, Hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs.
etiology:
Pathophysiology

Premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin within pancreas -> Autodigestion -> Inflammation -> SIRS.
exam:
Signs

Epigastric tenderness. Dehydration.
Red Flags: Cullen's (umbilicus) or Grey Turner's (flank) bruising = Hemorrhagic Necrosis.
inv:
Labs

Amylase/Lipase: >3x Upper Limit Normal. ABG (Lactate/Hypoxia). Calcium.

Imaging

USG (stones). CT Pancreas: After 48h for necrosis.
mgmt:
Supportive

Aggressive IV Fluids (Hartmann's), Analgesia (Opioids). Early enteral nutrition (NG/NJ).

Specific

ERCP (if cholangitis). Cholecystectomy (same admission).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Early: Shock, ARDS, Renal Failure (MODS), Hypocalcemia.
  • Late (>4 weeks): Pseudocyst, Walled-off Necrosis, Abscess.
  • Chronic: Diabetes, Malabsorption.
pearls:

PANCREAS mnemonic. Score â‰¥3 = Severe.

Common congenital anomaly predisposing to pancreatitis.

history:
HOPI

Painless progressive obstructive jaundice. Pruritus. Weight loss. Back pain (late). New onset diabetes in elderly.
etiology:
Risk Factors

Smoking, Chronic Pancreatitis, Diabetes, Obesity, Age >60, BRCA2/Lynch.
Pathology: Ductal Adenocarcinoma (85%).
exam:
Signs

Jaundice. Scratch marks. Cachexia.
Courvoisier's Sign: Palpable non-tender GB + Jaundice = Malignancy.
inv:
Labs

Cholestatic LFTs. CA 19-9. High INR.

Imaging

CT Pancreas: "Double duct sign". Staging (SMV/SMA invasion).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Biliary Obstruction.
  • Duodenal Obstruction.
  • Cachexia.
  • Thromboembolism.
Treatment Related

  • Delayed Gastric Emptying.
  • Diabetes.

etiology:
